question:
You are synthesizing a dialkylphosphate from two different enantiopure chiral alcohols and POCl3. In the first step, you reacted one equiv. of the first chiral alcohol with one equiv. of POCl3 (and some base). In the second step, you treated the product of this reaction with one equiv. of the second chiral alcohol (and some more base). In the final step, you add water to generate the final product. You are following the progress of the final reaction using 31P NMR.

What do you expect to see in the proton-decoupled 31P NMR spectrum over the course of the reaction? A:A single peak changing to two peaks  B:A single peak changing to another single peak C:Two peaks changing to three peaks  D:Two peaks changing to a single peak

logical_conclusion: step1: Identify the starting material in the final reaction as a dialkylphosphate intermediate with two different chiral alcohols attached
step2: Determine that this intermediate has two phosphorus-containing stereoisomers due to the two different chiral alcohols creating a new stereocenter at phosphorus
step3: Recognize that each stereoisomer will give a distinct signal in proton-decoupled 31P NMR
step4: Understand that hydrolysis will convert both stereoisomers to the same achiral dialkylphosphate product
step5: Conclude that the final product will show a single peak in 31P NMR
step6: Therefore, the spectrum will change from two peaks (stereoisomers) to a single peak (final product), corresponding to answer D

The final step involves the **conversion of the intermediate (R₁O–P(=O)(Cl)(OR₂))** to the **final product (R₁O–P(=O)(OH)(OR₂))**. As the reaction progresses:
